docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Iraqi Insurance Company Offers Terror Coverage Iraqis have begun to purchase the first off-the-shelf terrorism policy in the world, insurance experts say. It looks like an ordinary life insurance policy, but with added coverage for explosions caused by weapons of war and car bombs, assassinations and terrorist attacks. A1 Palestinians Try to Flee Iraq More than 100 Palestinians who fled Baghdad in the wake of increasing violence at the hands of Shiite militia are seeking refuge in Jordan. They have been denied entry by border officials for not having proper entry permits, a spokesman for the Jordanian government said. A8 Soldier Held in Bribery Scheme A member of the United States Army Corps of Engineers is accused of accepting thousands of dollars in bribes from a Kuwaiti rental agent who wanted to provide expensive apartments for American military employees in Kuwait, the Justice Department said. A9 U.S. Rejects Belarus Election The United States called the results of a presidential election in Belarus invalid and supported the call for a new race, even as President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko defiantly swept aside criticism and declared himself the winner of a third term. A6 Congo Warlord at Hague Court Thomas Lubanga, a former Congolese warlord went on trial at the International Criminal Court in The Hague. He is accused of kidnapping children and turning them into soldiers, messengers, cooks and sex slaves. A6 NATIONAL A10-15 Family Still Seeks Answers Two Years After Death As the second anniversary of the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman nears, his family remains frustrated by the Army's handling of the killing. But for the first time they may be close to getting answers. A1 911 Calls as Evidence Supreme Court justices questioned whether prosecutors can use a crime victim's emergency call to 911 as evidence without violating a defendant's constitutional right to face the accuser in the courtroom. A15 Western Drought Less Severe When the extremes of wet and dry are averaged out, the long Western drought, which began in the late 1990's, is still on but without some of its past punch. A10 G.O.P. Focuses on Unions With the election season heating up, the Bush administration and the Republican Party are wooing a group that has long been part of the Democrats' base: organized labor. A10 Support for Grizzly Protection Scientists from around the country asked the Fish and Wildlife Service not to lift the protections given to the Yellowstone grizzly bear by the Endangered Species Act. A15 EDUCATION Aiming High, With Extra Backup Students aiming for the most selective universities are now applying to as many as 10 or 12 colleges, guidance counselors and college admissions officials said. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6; 8 N.Y.U. and Columbia Receive $200 Million Each New York University and Columbia, which have both tried to raise their endowments, have received unrelated gifts of about $200 million each, among the largest bequests academic institutions in recent years. A1 Transit Contract Unsettled Three months after the December transit strike the city's transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are far from agreement on a new contract. B1 A Cold War-Era Stockpile City workers, conducting a regular inspection of the Brooklyn Bridge, uncovered a cold-war era hoard with provisions that would allow for basic survival if New York City were devastated by a nuclear attack. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Schizophrenia and Treatment A report suggests that when some people first develop psychosis they can function without medication -- or with far less than is typically prescribed -- as well as they can with the drugs. F1 Health & Fitness F5 ARTS E1-10 Biographer to Lead PEN Center The members of PEN American Center are expected to ratify Ron Chernow, the best-selling biographer of J. P. Morgan, John D. Rockefeller and Alexander Hamilton, to succeed Salman Rushdie as their president. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-20 Court Overturns Conviction A federal appeals court overturned the obstruction of justice conviction of Frank P. Quattrone, the investment banker who rose to prominence in the 1990's technology boom, and granted him a new trial. A1 Flight Perk Now Hard To Use Through pay cuts, shrunken pensions and longer hours, airline employees who survived the endless rounds of layoffs knew they could still count on one thing: free flights. But that perk, a touch of jet-setting glamour in an increasingly dreary line of work, is now much harder to use because so many flights are full. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: Deficit demagogues; extraditing Charles Taylor; slapping King Coal's wrist; Robert B. Semple Jr. on a Republican rara avis. Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof. Crossword E2 Obituaries B7 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: Appeals Court Reverses Conviction Of Former Investment Banker A federals appeals court overturned the conviction of Frank P. Quattrone, the investment banker who rose to prominence in the 1990's technology boom, on obstruction of justice charges, and granted him a new trial. The ruling, a rare reversal of a jury verdict, is a big setback for the government, which had sought to portray Mr. Quattrone as a symbol of Wall Street's excesses during the boom years. [Page A1.] Panel Faults Guidant on Heart Device Safety An expert panel commissioned by Guidant to review its handling of heart device flaws said that the company had systematically failed to fully assess patient safety in deciding whether to publicize product failures. [C1.] Microsoft Outlines Internet Software Strategy Microsoft faces a potent challenge as software is increasingly built and distributed as a service on the Internet. The company yesterday offered the most detailed glimpse to date of its strategic response: embrace the Internet software model, add its own offerings, and link the new technology to the coming version of its Windows Vista operating system. Speaking of his company's plan, Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman said: ''We will definitely have a comprehensive model. And there will be an integration benefit.'' [C4.] Google is introducing a financial information service intended to compete directly with offerings from Microsoft, Yahoo and others. [C5.] Oracle Reports 42% Increase in Profit for Quarter The Oracle Corporation reported a 42 percent increase in quarterly profit, but growth in its flagship database business was softer than expected. [C4.] Effects of Delphi Bankruptcy Spread Across Industry A bankruptcy filing by Delphi has engulfed General Motors, the United Automobile Workers and has splashed over other auto parts suppliers that have followed it into Chapter 11. Market Place. [C1.] New Fed Chairman Stresses Global Economics Ben S. Bernanke, the newly installed Federal Reserve chairman, suggested that the central bank would need to pay more attention to global financial conditions in setting interest rates, moving beyond its traditional focus on domestic economic forces. [C1.] Poultry Producers Prepare for Avian Flu Fears Poultry producers and restaurants doubt that their chickens will be infected by avian flu or that people would catch the virus even if there were to be contamination. But they are concerned that if the virus gets to the United States, people will eat less chicken -- simply out of fear. And they are revving up big plans to be prepared. [C1.] The World Health Organization says that despite agreements made earlier, many countries are still not promptly sharing information on avian influenza with the scientific community. [A5.] Bid for Insurer Spurs Talk of European Consolidation Aviva's bid for Prudential, one of Britain's largest life insurers, aroused speculation that consolidation would again sweep the industry. [C6.] Dell Announces Plan to Double India Work Force Dell, the world's largest maker of personal computers, plans to double the size of its work force in India, to 20,000, and is looking for a site for its manufacturing unit in the country, the company's chairman, Michael S. Dell, said. ''There is a fantastic opportunity to attract talent,'' Mr. Dell said, referring to the country's workers, many of whom are educated in technological fields and speak English. ''We will ensure a major recruitment push in engineering talents,'' he said during a visit to Bangalore, India's outsourcing capital. [C6.] Major U.S. Stock Indicators Are Mixed The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.12 points, to 11,274.53. Broader stock indicators were narrowly mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500 lost 2.17 points, to 1,305.08. The Nasdaq rose 7.63 points, to 2,314.11. [C9.] The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators fell 0.2 percent in February, after a revised 0.5 percent rise in January. [C9.] In a Violent Place, a New Type of Insurance In what is apparently an unprecedented move, the Iraq Insurance Company has sold about 200 individual terrorism policies in the last year, and is now negotiating with several government ministries and private companies for group policies that would cover thousands of employees. [A1.] Airline Workers Starting to Lose Free Flights Through deep pay cuts and layoffs, airline employees knew they could still count on one thing: free flights. But that perk is now much harder to use because so many flights are full. [A1.] Groups in France Call for More Protests on Labor Law French students and unions stepped up pressure on the government, calling for a day of demonstrations and strikes on March 28 to fight a new labor law that makes it easier for companies to fire young employees. [A9.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Three months after the December transit strike -- and amid an exchange of salvos issued far from the bargaining table -- the city's transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are far from agreement on a new contract. And they didn't get any closer yesterday, with both sides staking out positions that could carry significant risks.

headline.main: A New Transit Strike Is Unlikely. But How About a Deal?

docs.abstract: Transit Workers Union and Metropolitan Transportation Authority wage acrimonious battle over new contract months after New York City transit strike; union objects to recommendation for binding arbitration; union president Roger Toussaint wants MTA to honor second vote on contract rejected by workers in January, but authority says terms of that contract are off table; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city's transit workers both staked out positions Monday that could carry risks.

byline.original: By THOMAS J. LUECK and STEVEN GREENHOUSE

docs.lead_paragraph: A business trip is a great excuse to eat. Just ask George Pattee, the chief executive of the Parksite Group, a marketing company for specialty building products in Batavia, Ill. ''The temptation to eat fast food is constant,'' he said. ''The real challenge has always been the evening meal. Going out with clients and ordering a steak, that's part of the routine.''

headline.main: Hitting the Gym, Not the Vending Machine, on the Road

docs.abstract: Christopher Elliott Sounding Off column on how companies are increasingly looking for ways to make business travel healthier as health care costs rise; programs educate frequent travelers about healthy lifestyles using online journals, support groups and other technologies for wellness; description of Parksite Group's wellness program run by Com-Psyche Corp; travelers often resist changes related to diet and exercise (M)
docs.snippet: Corporate wellness programs seek to educate frequent travelers about the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle punctuated by deep-fried meals.

docs.lead_paragraph: City Councilman David I. Weprin, a Queens Democrat who is the Finance Committee chairman, said yesterday that he would reintroduce a bill to continue health insurance coverage for the spouse or domestic partner of a city retiree after the retiree's death. The bill, which Mr. Weprin proposed last year, was the subject of a hearing but was not voted on before the session ended. It would require the spouse or partner to pay 27 percent of the group rate for continued coverage and would cost $8 million a year at the outset, he said. The Bloomberg administration, which is trying to rein in the escalating cost of health insurance, pensions and fringe benefits, might oppose the measure. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bill For Retiree Insurance

docs.abstract: City Councilman David I Weprin will reintroduce bill to continue health insurance coverage for spouse or domestic partner of retired city worker after retiree's death (S)
docs.snippet: City Councilman David I. Weprin, a Queens Democrat who is the Finance Committee chairman, said yesterday that he would reintroduce a bill to continue health insurance coverage for the spouse or domestic partner of a city retiree after the retiree's...

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN (NYT); Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: One day last October, Karyn, a 39-year-old executive, pulled her online dating profile off JDate and Match.com, two sites she had been using, along with an endless series of leads, tips and blind dates arranged by friends and colleagues, to search for a man she wanted to marry and raise a family with. At long last, after something like 100 dates in the past 10 years and several serious relationships, she had found the man she refers to, tongue only slightly in cheek, as ''the one.'' It all began last summer, when she broke off a relationship with a younger man who wasn't ready for children and got serious about the idea of conceiving on her own. She gathered information about fertility doctors and sperm banks. ''Then a childhood friend of mine was over,'' she told me. ''I pulled up the Web site of the only sperm bank that I know of that has adult photos. There happened to be one Jewish person. I pulled up the photo, and I looked at my friend, and I looked at his picture, and I said, 'Oh, my God.' I can't say love at first sight, because, you know. But he was the one.''
docs.abstract: Jennifer Egan article on growing trend toward single motherhood with women selecting what they hope will be good genetic material from profiles of sperm donors; while lesbian couples have long been conceiving with donor sperm, idea is relatively new for heterosexual women who are watching their biological clocks tick but not meeting men with whom they want to raise families; support group Single Mothers by Choice enrolled double number of new members in 2005 as it did 10 years ago and business is booming for sperm banks; experiences of several women described; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Tired of waiting for the right guy to come along, more and more women are just looking for the right sperm. But for a woman trying to have a child alone, choosing a donor is only the beginning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people don't hesitate to insure their life, car or home. But insurance for long-term care? They'll think about it, thanks. It's not that people don't think they'll ever get old -- and, perhaps, be unable to care for themselves. But those huge premiums, year after year, off into the sunset, leave a nagging fear that the money might go down the drain. Perhaps people feel they might be able to fend for themselves till near the end, and the money saved on insurance might cover their last chapter. If not, there's always (they hope) Medicare. But it's all rather vague.

headline.main: Trying to Shed Light On the Muddle Of Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Excellus Health Plan study forecasts that 69 percent of all 65-year-olds will need long-term care and that half of those now turning 65 will face no out-of-pocket expenses; finds 6 percent, even those investing $100,000, will not be covered; chart (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders, concerned that many nonprofit hospitals are not providing enough charity care to justify their tax-exempt status, say they will set standards for the industry if it does not do so itself. The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who had already been examining nonprofit groups like United Way and the American Red Cross, is broadening his focus to include nonprofit hospitals, with an eye to legislation that would clarify standards for their tax exemptions. Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, began investigating the financial practices of nonprofit hospitals last year.

headline.main: Nonprofit Hospitals Face Scrutiny Over Practices

docs.abstract: Chairman of Senate Finance Committee Charles E Grassley is broadening his examination of nonprofit groups to include hospitals, with eye to legislation that would clarify standards for their tax exemptions; concern is that non-profit hospitals do not provide enough charity care to justify exemptions and that they are aggressive in their billing and debt collection practices; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Congressional leaders, concerned that many nonprofit hospitals are not providing enough charity care, say they will set standards if the industry does not do so itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: With a strong directive from the Bush administration, Congress set out more than a year ago to fashion legislation that would protect America's private pension system, tightening the rules to make sure companies set aside enough money to make good on their promises to employees. Then the political horse-trading began, with lawmakers, companies and lobbyists, representing everything from big Wall Street firms to tiny rural electric cooperatives, weighing in on the particulars of the Bush administration's blueprint.

headline.main: MAJOR CHANGES RAISE CONCERNS ON PENSION BILL

docs.abstract: Lawmakers have modified many rules designed to protect America's private pension system, giving companies more time to cover pension shortfalls, allowing them to make forgiving estimates of future obligations, and even sometimes letting them assume their workers will die younger than rest of population; bill now being completed in House-Senate conference committee would actually weaken system; shortfall raises specter of more plans failing and forcing their liabilities on government; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Lawmakers have modified the bill to the point of weakening the pension system rather than strengthening it.

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge in Somerset County Superior Court signed an order on Thursday that would allow the convicted serial killer Charles Cullen to donate one of his kidneys as long as he and his doctors met a new series of conditions, including providing a guarantee that the recipient's insurance would pay all costs. The order leaves in question when the transplant could take place. Mr. Cullen's lawyer said on Friday that he was concerned that New Jersey officials might yet try to ''sabotage'' his client's effort to donate the organ.

headline.main: Judge Sets Conditions to Allow Serial Killer to Donate Kidney

docs.abstract: Judge Paul A Armstrong of Somerset County, NJ, Superior Court allows serial killer Charles Cullen to donate kidney to relative in New York, provided certain criteria are met, including guarantee that recipient's insurance will pay all costs; former nurse admits to killing 29 patients in New Jersey and Pennsylvania (M)
